div.p: Well how are you? I am fine and dandy, and enjoying My self very murch This is a real pretty country or I like it better than I thought I would
The only thing I dont like is I cant talk to these people here or cant understand what they are trying to say I have learned a few words and before long I can talk to them some I thank.
There is a bunch in the
Camp all day Selling nuts orngs and several other things So I get to see lots sights
I dont thank I will be able to make love to these girls for some time and maybe the war will soon be over any way
I wrote you a letter before I landed off the boat I dont know wheather you will get it or not
But I will tell you about My trip across the pond and I could tell it in a few words I didint like it a bit I was sea sick a couple of days
smoothe most all the way but when they got rough was when I got sick and I wasnt by my self either There was a lot of the boys that were sick
I have had a long trip on railroad since I landed I got to see lots of this country I will say one thing these people all live in brick or stone house
There is not any wood houses at all not even the a dog house of wood We have wood house in the Camp and that is the only ones I see
I think we will soon go to work and I will
be real good when we do I have drilled so murch I am tired of it I had rather work any duty than to drill
Well Ellen I cant tell you any thing More we cant tell murch. I will write you ever chance I have and I want you to write me real often I will be awful glad to here from the good old U.S.
In the letter I wrote you on the boat I gave you my address but it would be better if it was this way
Well I will close for this time
Hoping to here from you real soon
